content.title: Guide to Contrast, Accessibility, and Colors

contrast.title: Accessibility (WCAG)
contrast.description1: The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) set standards to make web content accessible for people with disabilities. Contrast ratios vary depending on the background color. Pigmenta allows testing against both light and dark backgrounds to ensure compliance with WCAG standards.
contrast.description2: A good contrast ratio is crucial for readability. Level AA requires a 4.5:1 contrast for normal text and 3:1 for large text. Level AAA, the most stringent, requires 7:1 and 4.5:1, respectively. When the contrast ratio is below 3:1, Pigmenta marks it as ‘Fail’, indicating that the color is not suitable even for large text according to WCAG 2.1. It is recommended to adjust brightness or saturation to improve accessibility.

opacity.title: Opacity (Transparency)
opacity.description1: Opacity defines the level of transparency of a color. A value of 100% (or 1 in CSS) means the color is completely opaque, while a value of 0% (or 0) makes it completely transparent.
opacity.description2: It is often represented in the RGBA color model (Red, Green, Blue, Alpha), where 'Alpha' is the opacity channel. It's fundamental for creating visual effects like overlays or semi-transparent backgrounds in UI design.

deltaE.title: Color Difference (Delta E)
deltaE.description1: Delta E (∆E) is a metric that quantifies the difference between two colors as perceived by the human eye. A low value (less than 1) indicates the difference is imperceptible, while a high value (greater than 5) indicates a noticeable difference.
deltaE.description2: It's a useful tool for ensuring that your brand's colors remain consistent across different media or devices.

uxColors.title: Colors for Your UX/UI
uxColors.description1: The choice of colors directly impacts the user experience. Warm colors (red, orange) evoke energy and attention, while cool colors (blue, green) convey calmness and trust. It's vital to use colors with purpose and maintain a coherent palette.
